replies.body: Well, if he's not being played in a duo lane, the bonus exp isn't really factoring significantly into his power budget. We couldn't use the removal of something that isn't contributing significant amounts of power as an excuse to introduce a mechanic that would increase power. The discussion of whether or not we can afford to buff him through a new mechanic is separate from the discussion of whether we should remove a mechanic that isn't contributing power.

How about dropping the dragon mechanic instead? It was just a cheesy attempt to provide siege power to a bot lane with Mordekaiser.

It's still frustrating to me that what Mordekaiser needed was reliable CC or mobility, and instead we get this weird reworked monstrosity instead, which was almost immediately nerfed into the floor and left in irrelevance after the AD item rework.

>what Mordekaiser needed was reliable CC or mobility,

That's also what a lot of Morde players didn't want him to have. A very common idea among Morde players is that he is defined by being the damaging drain-tank that doesn't have mobility or CC. That's what they liked, and that is what Riot tried to deliver on. Even among all the criticism that was dropped on this rework, this particular point was actually well-received.

>How about dropping the dragon mechanic instead?

There could be an argument for replacing the dragon mechanic with something else. Of course, it would depend on what exactly we want to replace it with.

I'm of the opinion that a drain tank is rather ineffective if they can't get to anyone to drain.

Swain is basically a drain tank, and he has two forms of CC, as well as reliable spells to continuously renew the slow on Rylai's.

I think my main issue with the whole thing is that he's in the juggernaut sub-class, when you look at juggernauts they have an issue with being kited around, but each of them has their own way to keep up, or slow people down.

{{champion:122}} Has a strong slow in addition to his pull.
{{champion:72}} has a mobility boost and two forms of hard CC in his kit.
{{champion:86}} Has a speed up that also removes slows.
{{champion:420}} has a slow in addition to a short range dash.

I'm not sure if I'm missing any, but I would guarantee that they have their own cc and/or mobility to them. Getting kited as a juggernaut feels pretty bad, but being kited as Mordekaiser feels so much worse due to his lack of ability to compensate in any form.

The old form of Mordekaiser at least did solid damage and got rewarded with substantial survivability. Now his damage is burst through sustained fighting, it just doesn't feel like it works properly.

You're starting to get into arguments I don't really care about. I have my own opinions about Morde's kitability, but it's just not an interesting topic to me. My point was only that low CC and low mobility is exactly what Morde players wanted. The sore point for most players is that they lost power on the E that made the old playstyle work, not that he stayed immobile and low-CC.

>The old form of Mordekaiser at least did solid damage and got rewarded with substantial survivability.

Better post work?????!?!?!???!    What are you talking about.   Before it was a reliable lvl based progression and its shield decay was nÃ©gligeable

Now its Health based. Fyi Morde has the worst Health of any champion @ lvl 18.  The shield decay happens so quickly you may aswell not have a shield at times

>That's also what a lot of Morde players didn't want him to have.

I agreed back then, on the assumption that because a champion was being made that had no cc or mobility whatsoever, the rest of his kit would be godly considering how powerful and impactful those two things are. Think of the power budget he'd have to work with when there's not big chunks of it being ripped out for crowd control and dashes!

Unfortunately, Riot appears to extremely undervalue mobility when it comes to power budgets. When you have champions that are blinking and tumbling all over the place, they don't seem to give up much in return for that huge boost in power. Morde could probably have some form of noticeable mobility placed into his kit if he gave up 3 base AD. Maybe 5 if it's point and click.

The question then becomes, should he be given mobility? If mobility is being given away dirt cheap and is so damn powerful, is it irresponsible to to give that up because tradition says Morde is immobile? These are questions that Morde players really have to sit down and ask themselves. Shame on Riot for putting the Morde players in this position in the first place.

>There could be an argument for replacing the dragon mechanic with something else.

There would be, if the dragon ghost took any power budget at all. There was a red post way back when that stated that since the ability CD was basically 6+ minutes, that it took practically nothing from his budget. If it was removed, it wouldn't free up all that much. Like mobility, it takes up so little of his budget, but has a huge impact on the game. It would be silly to give that up.

The W passive, on the other hand, was something Morde got nerfed to hell and back for having. His base stats got hit hard because he naturally gained a level advantage over his opponents. Yes, Morde rarely goes bot to use the passive anymore, but he'll never get that power back as long as the potential for that 100% pick/ban rate in bot lane remains a possibility.

It's not that the ability has no cost because Morde never uses it, it's actually more like Morde is paying for an ability he never uses. _Huge_ difference.

> It's not that the ability has no cost because Morde never uses it, it's actually more like Morde is paying for an ability he never uses. *Huge difference.*

Good point.

>There would be, if the dragon ghost took any power budget at all.

Yes, this is probably true. In power terms, it certainly isn't a major contributor.

>but he'll never get that power back as long as the potential for that 100% pick/ban rate in bot lane remains a possibility.

I disagree. If he's currently stronger in solo lanes (which he is), and he's barely touching viability in bot lane (also true), and he's received balance changes since then specifically aimed at placing him in solo lanes, then this isn't taking up any part power budget. It's more akin to the AP ratio on Jinx's chompers than it is to a legitimate point of balance.

>as long as the potential for that 100% pick/ban rate in bot lane remains a possibility

To be frank, that potential is completely dead, and the reason it is dead is because he's been balanced to be stronger in solo lanes. He'd hit a point of 100% solo pick/ban before he hit a duo pick/ban. It would take balance changes specifically directed at his duo lane to make this a problem again, and Riot has the option of just not doing that.

It's not a part of his power budget because it isn't utilized in his strongest role, and his weaker role is significantly weaker than his stronger one. It may have been a balance limiter in the past, but to say it still is disregards all the balance changes he has had since the rework.

>and he's received balance changes since then specifically aimed at placing him in solo lanes, then this isn't taking up any part power budget. It's more akin to the AP ratio on Jinx's chompers than it is to a legitimate point of balance.

This is bullshit, and I'll tell you why.

The major changes Morde went through to become viable in solo lanes? He can now cast his W alone or on a minion. That's almost the full extent of those "changes since then specifically aimed at placing him in solo lanes" after he got nerfed in all roles for dominating worlds. He can still use his W to full effectiveness in a duo lane.

Unlike a lot of other champions, Morde is in a unique position that he's getting buffs delayed because he might become too much of a problem in a role that he almost never goes in. That's both insane and insanely unfair. Removing the W passive, despite Morde getting nearly no value from it, would indeed open him up to buffs by removing the fear of him dominating bot lane once again. It has no numerical power in his budget, but it has to be budgeted numerically in his power.

And the Jinx comparison? I don't remember anyone running around dominating a major tourney with AP Jinx. And I damn sure don't remember Jinx getting nerfed down to almost unplayable levels because someone was building deathcap on her and going mid. The context is completely different between the two abilities, despite the situation of "this is worth nothing to the kit" being similar. The context difference is that Jinx can still get buffs despite her AP ratio, Morde can't because of his W passive.

No W passive = No bot lane Morde = No fear of buffs from Riot = More power to Morde's kit.
It's a bit roundabout, but the W passive still holds power in Morde's budget. It's just power that's more political than numerical.

>That's almost the full extent of those "changes since then specifically aimed at placing him in solo lanes"

Yes, and they were enough to make him strictly better in a solo lane than he is in a duo lane. That's how easy it was to make him a solo laner. His kit is not well-suited to duo laning, and never was. The only reason he was ever overpowered in a solo lane was because he was specifically restricted from going into a solo lane. As soon as the restrictions were removed,. 

He'll become OP in a solo lane long before he's op in a duo lane. 

>Morde is in a unique position that he's getting buffs delayed because he might become too much of a problem in a role that he almost never goes in. 

I think that is completely wrong. It presumes that there are no buffs that we can give that would help him in a solo lane more than a duo lane, and I think that's just bullshit. It doesn't fly.

I would agree with the claim that our number of options for buffing Morde are limited by the presence of his ability to go bot lane, but it absolutely does not change our ability to increase his solo lane power more than his duo lane.

>The context is completely different between the two abilities, despite the situation of "this is worth nothing to the kit" being similar.

The historical context is different, but the current game situation is not different. Jinx can be buffed despite having an element that is worthless to her kit, and so can Morde. The only difference is that Morde's could still theoretically become part of his power budget again, so we have to tailor buffs so that they don't allow this. That is not a hard task.

I have an alternative explanation for why Morde hasn't received buffs: He's reasonably close to being in a balanced state, and Riot knows he's terribly designed right now. They hate applying balance changes to champions they know they'll need to rework unless they're extremely out of line. That's why they're sitting on Morde. It's not because they're scared of buffing him; it's because they don't want to.
Ok so your saying just nerf him?

I said that if we wanted to give him a new mechanic, and if he is currently balanced, then we'd have to remove something that actually gives him power to open up room in the power budget. Whether or not we should do that, and whether or not he is currently balanced, are things I didn't touch on.

Removing something from his kit with no compensation is where i drew the nerf conclusion.   My point is. Riot. Shouldnt build a champion around a role that noone plays them.   Bonus exp is wasted part of his kit

I did not say to remove something with no compensation. You wanted to add something. That would be the compensation. Or do you intend to add something with no power.

The bonus xp may be a wasted part of his kit when he solo lanes, but it is NOT part of his power budget. Removing it would not open up any of his power budget for buffs.

uhm, every part of a champion's kit is part of their "power budget". That's why it's called a "power budget".

A champion has a "budget" of power. So a portion goes here, a portion goes there - nothing is irrelevant to a champ's power budget, because if it affects how they perform it's part of their balancing levers.

I mean, that's like saying that nerfing Sona's powerchord is NOT part of his power budget. Uh, it is. Her other abilities are weaker to compensate.

Morde is the same way - Riot has adjusted his per-level base damages and benefits to be balanced around him being in a duo lane with bonus XP. Just because they've since moved his kit away from a duo lane does not mean that the bonus XP doesn't eat up part of his power budget.

It couldn't be coupled with a major "compensation" buff, certainly, but removing the mechanic that makes him function bottom lane (even if it's not a role he's played in anymore) wouldn't just HAPPEN unless he was experiencing SIGNIFICANT successes in another lane in spite of that, and I feel that Morde is still almost never picked and isn't outrageously strong or anything, so that isn't the case.

What he's saying is this:

1. Morde currently does not use the XP passive, so 
* So no, the XP passive  doesn't affect how he perform, it doesn't contribute to his current level of power.
* So the "portion", as you put it, of the XP passive in his power budget is null or negligible.
* So removing the XP passive would not free any meaningful budget to buff him elsewhere.

He also implied that **maybe** Morde could be straight out buffed (IF he's too weak right now), but his main point was that removing the XP passive would NOT allow to buff him in compensation.

I kinda disagree with his reasoning, because Morde still pays for the **potential** use he could get from this passive, **if** he was played bot. It's more like he's paying for the passive he doesn't use, than like he's not paying anything because he doesn't use it. But still, you need to understand his argument before dismissing it.

Before we start this, I want to say that if your argument is that the bonus exp is technically a very, very, small part of his power budget, then my response is that it is so small that it is completely insignificant. I don't care about any argument that says it maybe comprises 0.01% of his power, because that is negligible. In practical terms, he'd be just as strong if he didn't have it as if he did.

>every part of a champion's kit is part of their "power budget"

No, it's not. If you have an aspect of a champion's kit that isn't part of that champion's play in the role they are balanced around, then it isn't part of their power budget. This is why we differentiate "power budget" and "kit mechanics". A champion's kit makes up everything they have: a champion's power budget only incorporates things that they actually use.

> Riot has adjusted his per-level base damages and benefits to be balanced around him being in a duo lane with bonus XP.

Yes, and then they had to do multiple balance and design changes to move him away from that. Those balance changes caused him to be played in a way where the bonus XP was no longer a significant part of his power budget. 

>I mean, that's like saying that nerfing Sona's powerchord is NOT part of his power budget. 

Sona uses her powercord. Morde doesn't use his bonus XP. Completely different. This is more akin to saying that Poppy's AP ratios aren't part of her power budget, which would also be accurate.

>Just because they've since moved his kit away from a duo lane does not mean that the bonus XP doesn't eat up part of his power budget.

That is exactly what it means. If Morde is strongest when he's in a solo lane, then he's strongest when he's getting no benefit from this passive. That means it isn't part of his power budget. It's as simple as that. If he's not using it, it's not in his power budget. It's only part of his kit.

>It couldn't be coupled with a major "compensation" buff, 

Forget "major". It couldn't be coupled with any compensation buff, because it's not affecting his power in any meaningful way. Whether or not he should get a buff is completely separate from any discussion of the bonus XP. because the bonus XP is completely unrelated to his power level.

I'm gonna stop you right now.

**THE GAME DOESN'T END AT LANING PHASE.**

Being able to get full exp for any creeps you last hit when your **ENTIRE ALLIED TEAM IS THERE** is pretty powerful, whether you believe it to be or not. 

This is my problem with all of the arguments saying "he doesn't use the exp passive" - does he disable it somehow? does Morde not put points into his W? Because when the jungler ganks and you push together, is he not using it? When bot lane rotates to help you push, is that not using the passive? When you get a dragon ghost and group with your team to push, is that not using the passive?

Just because it's no longer an integral part of his laning phase doesn't mean it's completely superfluous. Did I say it's a good passive, or that it's particularly beneficial to Morde? No. But saying that because he doesn't use it in the laning phase it isn't part of his power budget (or is only a small part of his power budget) is ridiculous. Dragon Ghost is harder to utilize as top lane Morde than your W passive - does that mean it's not part of his power budget too? Mordekaiser can get solo exp no matter how many targets are near him as long as he gets the last hit - this is powerful. Any buffs or nerfs to Morde that didn't take this account would just catapult him back into bullshit bottom-lane territory, and that's why you have to consider it when buffing/nerfing Morde, even if it's "unrelated" to his power level - right now it is, but in the future it could easily be the lynchpin that makes him broken again.

Like seriously, look at {{champion:268}} for an example of a champion's complexity and small mechanics pushing them into OP land. Start buffing him and all of a sudden his utility is just too overpowered! The same thing could easily happen to put Morde bottom lane again, as long as the W passive exists, and so it's not "unrelated" to his power level in any way. Just because it's not directly contributing to his current power doesn't mean you can ignore it when balancing Morde.

>THE GAME DOESN'T END AT LANING PHASE.

I know. I made my argument knowing that. It is negligible when he's solo laning, even with this taken into account.

>But saying that because he doesn't use it in the laning phase it isn't part of his power budget

Correction: He doesn't use it during the laning phase, and it's incredibly weak outside of the laning phase.

>Being able to get full exp for any creeps you last hit when your ENTIRE ALLIED TEAM IS THERE is pretty powerful, 

I'm going to disagree. The vast majority of solo Morde's CS throughout the game is going to come without any allies being around, and by the time of the game where this does start to come into play even a little, xp differences that minor become extremely weak. 

It is as nonfunctional to a power budget as any mechanic in the game. Even just saying that this gives him power is overvaluing it by an ungodly degree.

>Dragon Ghost is harder to utilize as top lane Morde than your W passive - does that mean it's not part of his power budget too? 

No, because it still has some potential strength that he can tap, even if he does so rarely. The XP passive doesn't. 

> Any buffs or nerfs to Morde that didn't take this account would just catapult him back into bullshit bottom-lane territory, and that's why you have to consider it when buffing/nerfing Morde,

That's an entirely new argument. It's also one I happen to agree with. Morde's potential to go bot lane does mean that when he gets buffed, certain buffs aren't options because they would support bot lane more than solo lane. That is a design limitation.

Now, that doesn't mean that the XP passive is currently part of his power budget. Instead, what it means is that it has the potential to be part of his power budget, and we have to impose design constraints to avoid this. That is a good argument for removing it, and I suspect Riot will do so at some point in the future for this reason, particularly if they ever rework Morde.

It also doesn't mean that his power is limited as a result of this design limitation. We have already proved that we can buff Morde while helping his solo lane more than the bot lane. That means that we can continue to ignore the XP passive, so long as we are comfortable with limiting his design options as a result. (I'm not saying we should be comfortable with limiting his design: just that we can easily alter his power at will without risk of bot-lane Morde so long as we do).

>Like seriously, look at for an example of a champion's complexity and small mechanics pushing them into OP land.

I wouldn't say that it is small mechanics that are making Azir unbalancable. It's his entire kit. His problem is that by design, he has an answer to every situation, so long as you and your teammates can afford to play very passively during the stage where you are weak.

Having an answer to every situation is not a complaint anyone could ever lodge against Morde.

>The same thing could easily happen to put Morde bottom lane again, as long as the W passive exists, and so it's not "unrelated" to his power level in any way. 

This assumes that we can't buff Morde without risking his bot lane becoming a problem again. That's just not true. We've already proved that we can alter the relative strength of Morde's roles through selective buffs. We can continue to do so easily in the future. That means we can buff him as we choose without risking bot-lane Morde. That's how we got away with reintroducing solo-lane Morde in the first place.

Again, the problem with the XP passive is that it imposes design constraints, not that it imposes power constraints. We can easily give him whatever power level we want without bot-lane Morde, but we have to avoid certain buffs to do it. That's not a good thing, but it's a different problem than the one you're talking about.
